metadata./Title: Primary anaplastic T-cell lymphoma of the omentum presenting as small bowel obstruction and complicated with Massilia timonae infection: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma primarily involving the omentum is an extremely rare entity with variable clinical presentation. Owing to its rarity and nonspecific clinical manifestation, omental T-cell lymphoma is often 
diagnosed at a later stage, riddled with complications. While imaging modalities such as computed tomography 
scan can help a physician reach a diagnosis, cases that present with complications may require a multidisciplinary 
approach that combines surgical exploration along with consultation from Oncology.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We hereby report a rare case of a 66-year-old African American male patient who presented 
to the emergency department with complaints of acute gastrointestinal obstruction. A computed tomography scan 
of the abdomen and pelvis revealed evidence of an internal hernia and surgical exploration revealed a hemorrhagic 
and infarcted omentum. Biopsies along with immunophenotypic studies confirmed the diagnosis of anaplastic T-cell 
lymphoma of the omentum complicated by Massilia timonae infection.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion The case highlights the significance of considering lymphoma, although rare, as a differential in a patient 
who presents with small bowel obstruction and the importance of investigating for malignancy for early diagnosis 
and treatment of primary omental lymphomas, before complications develop.
Keywords  Omental lymphoma, Small bowel lymphoma, Internal hernia, Small bowel obstruction, Case report
Background
Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (ALCL), a rare subtype 
of non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, was first identified in 1985 
by Stein et  al. [1]. It represents about 2% of adult cases 
of non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas in the USA [2]. ALCL 
is classified into anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)positive and ALK-negative subtypes on the basis of the 
expression of the ALK gene. ALK-negative ALCL is more 
aggressive, typically occurring in individuals aged 50–60, 
while ALK-positive ALCL occurs in younger patients and 
responds well to therapy [3]. ALCL commonly affects the 
lymph nodes, with extra-nodal involvement such as skin, 
bone, lung, and liver [4]. T-cell lymphomas involving the 
omentum are exceptionally rare, comprising only 8% of Open Access

all bowel malignancies [5]. Primary omental involvement 
of ALCL is extremely uncommon and presents with non specific symptoms such as vomiting, abdominal pain, 
and weight loss. Occasionally, it may be complicated by 
internal hernias or intussusception [6]. This case report 
highlights a unique instance of T-cell lymphoma primar ily affecting the omentum, presenting with symptoms of 
acute gastrointestinal obstruction, and later complicated 
by Massilia timonae infection.
Case presentation
The patient was an African American male in his 60s 
with a past medical and family history negative for 
cancer, who presented with constipation, multiple 
episodes of vomiting, and the inability to keep any thing down for 2 weeks. His physical examination was 
remarkable for tachycardia and abdominal distension 
without tenderness, guarding, or rigidity, and there 
was no palpable lymphadenopathy. In the emergency 
department, he was found to have a serum white blood 
cell count of 44,000 per microliter, which did not cor relate with his counts in the past, and his serum lactic 
acid was 3.7  mmol per liter. His chest x-ray revealed 
a right-sided elevated hemidiaphragm and computed 
tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis 
revealed evidence of internal hernia with obstructive 
changes, following which he underwent exploratory 
laparotomy. Exploration revealed a hemorrhagic and 
infarcted omentum and diffuse inflammation of the 
small bowel and ascites, and a subtotal omentectomy 
was performed with the release of bowel and place ment of a negative pressure device; samples of ascitic 
fluid and the omentum were sent for pathology. After 
1 day, he was reoperated with abdominal washout and 
abdominal wound vacuum-assisted closure placement; 
during this procedure, the bowel was found to be more 
edematous with a woody texture and dense adhesions 
were present. He had a third revision the following 
day with attempts for closure, however, it was unsuc cessful as the bowel remained edematous but viable; 
a liver biopsy was also performed here. The ascitic 
fluid cytology was positive for neoplasm with diffuse 
CD45 positivity, and the markers were negative for 
MOC 31, CEA, calretinin, D2-40, TTF–1, BER–EP 4, 
CK7, CK20, CDX2, and SOX10; his ascitic fluid cul tures also grew Massilia timonae. The patient was 
continued on meropenem and micafungin as broadspectrum coverage of intraabdominal infection in the 
setting of malignancy-related bowel disease. Due to 
the omentum’s morphology, and with its pathology 
displaying strong, uniform CD30 expression, loss of 
multiple T-cells markers (including CD5, CD7, CD8, 
CD56, ALK-1, CD20, PAX5, CD10, cyclin D1, CD138, and HHV-8), the diagnosis of ALK-negative anaplastic 
large-cell lymphoma, presumably stage IV, was favored 
over peripheral T-cell lymphoma with CD30 expres sion (Figs.  1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6). Other positive tumor mark ers were CD2, CD3, CD4, Bcl-6, MUM1, and MYC.

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Primary omental tumors are usually malignant and 
sporadic [7 ]. Common types include fibrosarcoma, 
spindle cell sarcoma, liposarcoma, leiomyoma, heman giopericytoma, lipoma, desmoid tumors, fibroma, 
mesothelioma, myosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, leio myoblastoma, and endothelioma [8 ]. However, ALCL 
primarily involving the omentum has not been reported 
before.
Fig. 3 400× CD3 showing membranous positivity
Fig. 4 400× strong CD4 positivity confirming that this is a T-cell 
and not NK-cell lymphoma; B-cell markers CD20 and Pax5 are 
negative
Fig. 5 200×, neoplasm as being CD30 positive
Fig. 6 400×, neoplasm as being ALK negative

ALCL is characterized by syncytial aggregates of large 
anaplastic lymphocytes with horse-shaped nuclei and a 
strong CD30 expression [9 ]. There is a strong predilec tion for the involvement of lymph node sinuses, with 
variable clinical presentation, usually peaking in the 
sixth decade with a male predominance [10].
Omental tumors are often asymptomatic but may 
cause abdominal discomfort, nausea, early satiety, B 
symptoms, or the presence of palpable mass [11]. They 
are challenging to diagnose radiologically and are often 
discovered after complications or histopathological 
examination post-surgery. Similarly, in our case, the 
patient was diagnosed with anaplastic T-cell lymphoma 
only after the symptoms had arisen due to hemor rhagic infarction and Massilia timonae infection, which 
speaks for the challenge in diagnosing this disease.
Abdominal CT scan may show varying presenta tions such as bowel wall thickening, pseudoaneurysmal 
dilatation, or clumped small bowel loops, giving the 
impression of a closed loop obstruction due to inter nal hernia, as in our case, which is rare [10]. The CT 
scan should also look for signs of submucosal edema 
in the form of circumferential thickening and hyper dense appearance of the bowel wall to assess the sever ity of the patient’s condition [12]. Differential diagnoses 
include small bowel adenocarcinoma, cecal tumors, 
infectious or inflammatory bowel wall thickening, car cinoid syndrome, or gastrointestinal stromal tumor 
[12]. In this case, histopathology confirmed the diagno sis of anaplastic T-cell lymphoma of the omentum.
About 90% of primary GI lymphomas are B-cell nonHodgkin’s lymphomas, while T-cell non-Hodgkin’s lym phomas are a comparatively rare occurrence [13]. It is 
important to make a pathologic distinction between the 
different subtypes of lymphomas because they have dif ferent clinical prognoses and treatment strategies. In 
our case, the patient expressed strong uniform CD30 
positivity. Apart from ALCL, CD30 positivity is also 
seen in classic Hodgkin’s lymphoma, enteropathy-asso ciated T-cell lymphoma, peripheral T-cell lymphoma, 
primary effusion lymphoma, diffuse large-cell lym phoma, and plasmablastic lymphoma [14]. The absence 
of Reed–Sternberg cells and other B-cell markers such 
as CD-20, CD-138, and CD-79a helped us rule out 
Hodgkin’s lymphoma. In addition, the tumor cells were 
positive for CD30, CD45 (diffuse), CD2, CD3, CD4, 
Bcl-6, MUM1, and MYC. The strong membranous and 
Golgi body-associated expression of CD30, loss of mul tiple T-cell markers such as CD5, CD7, CD8, CD56, 
ALK-1, CD20, PAX5, CD10, cyclin D1, CD138, and 
HHV-8, and tumor cell morphology allowed the diag nosis of ALK-negative anaplastic large-cell lymphoma 
to be made.Only a few cases of ALCL presenting as small bowel 
obstruction have previously been reported in the litera ture. Carey et  al. reported four cases of ALCL in men 
with a mean age of 56.8 years, of whom two had intestinal 
obstruction [9]. One patient had painless jaundice and 
pruritus with histological findings, revealing evidence 
of ALCL in the duodenum and jejunum. Whipple pro cedure was performed but the patient died due to sepsis 
6  months following the diagnosis. The second patient 
had periumbilical pain on presentation and CT showed 
the duodenum as the primary site of involvement. The 
patient was treated with segmental resection and chemo therapy. Upon follow-up, the patient was doing well with 
no evidence of the disease. With the omentum as the 
primary site of involvement, our patient’s presentation 
stood out from the reported cases in literature.
Ultimately, the treatment of primary GI lymphomas 
depends on the extent and type of disease [15]. The first 
line of treatment for ALCL is chemotherapy [15]. How ever, more complicated cases may require surgical inter vention or radiotherapy. Here, due to the severity of the 
patient’s condition, the patient’s family opted for pal liative care, and aggressive treatment options were not 
pursued.
Conclusion
Small bowel obstruction caused by ALCL primarily 
involving the omentum is a rare occurrence. This case 
highlights the significance of considering lymphoma, 
although rare, as a differential in a patient who presents 
with small bowel obstruction and investigating for malig nancy to allow for early diagnosis and treatment of pri mary omental lymphomas before complications develop. 
More research is needed to understand the progression, 
etiology, and ideal treatment modalities in a case of pri mary omental ALCL.
